Text:
Bangalore-based friends Tanya, Sindra, Indu and Veena tell the story behind their much feted short film Reminiscence of Ether

Two Indian women at an elite social gathering in London meet and fall in love. When one of them wants to adopt a child, differences crop up leading to arguments and heartbreak. This is the premise of Reminiscence of Ether, a short fiction film that won the audience award for best short fiction film at the 5th Bangalore Queer film festival and was one of 19 films (out of 373) selected and screened at the 15th International Women’s Film festival in Seoul last month.

Quite an achievement for the all-women team, a bunch of Bangalore-based friends, Tanya, Sindra, Indu and Veena, who had no formal training or experience in film-making before. The girls were toying with script writing and decided to make a film to feature in the upcoming Bangalore queer film festival. Tanya Tyagi, a marketing professional who authored the film’s script says, “This film is essentially about relationships and the turns they take with life and growth; the queer factor was just a natural part of the story flow, the emphasis being on the relationships.”

Tanya and Sindra put in their money to produce the film while Veena Kulkarni, a freelance corporate trainer, directed the film as the friends felt she had the best holistic approach. She learnt the art of film- making by watching ‘You Tube’ videos and the effort seems to have paid off as she was nominated for Riyad Wadia award for Emerging Filmmaker at the Kashish Mumbai International Film Festival held in June.

Indu Anthony, a professional photographer who took charge of the cinematography says that it was a whole new experience for her but also a lot of fun. “For the first scene where one of the protagonists, Rukhsaar, appears sad and teary-eyed, I kept the actress awake all night to get the right mood and feel.”

Of the evocative title, Veena says the significance of the title becomes clear during the narrative. “Rukhsaar is at the crossroads of life and is being pulled into her past while carving a path into the future”.

Talks are on to release the 20-minute film at a multiplex, but it’s not an easy proposition. It may have a niche audience but Veena is confident that “people will watch, though we cannot expect them to pay much. As independent film-makers, we are not looking to make money.” Indu also believes that, “just as IPL gained popularity, short fiction films too are a growing trend and will be popular.”

While there has been a spurt of queer writing and films since the 2009 High Court ruling decriminalising homosexuality, one wonders if there is a palpable change in attitude towards the LGBT community. Indu says: “there is a change, but not to extent where public display of affection is accepted.” Besides, in a country where talking about female sexuality is almost non-existent, even taboo, the task of portraying intimate scenes between gay women can be challenging. Tanya, who also plays one of the protagonists, was initially sceptical about the intimate scenes; “however it was handled well by the team and generated a positive response from the audience.”

Veena on the other hand says, “While shooting, it was just us and not a big deal. The scenes fit naturally in the story and being aesthetically choreographed, the audience received it well. Some film festivals, however, didn’t accept it because of that.”

So, what’s next? The team is currently focusing on showcasing the film at film festivals; it’s being screened at the San Francisco DesiQ film festival and in Chennai this month.

# **Scene Concept: Indie Film Production Studio "EchoFrame Collective"**  

## **1. Overall Scene Theme and Core Concept**  
A small, bustling indie film production studio—**EchoFrame Collective**—where an all-women team is preparing for a critical screening of their award-winning short film, *Reminiscence of Ether*. The studio is a repurposed warehouse loft, now a chaotic yet creative hive of activity. The space is inherently collaborative, with multiple specialized workstations (editing bays, prop storage, set construction) requiring coordination.  

**Why Multi-Agent?**  
- Heavy equipment movement (cameras, lighting rigs) requires multiple people.  
- Time-sensitive tasks (final edits, last-minute prop fixes) demand parallel workflows.  
- Information asymmetry (only the director knows the final edit; only the cinematographer knows the lighting setup).  

---

## **2. Spatial Layout and Area Descriptions**  

### **A. Main Editing & Screening Lounge**  
- **Purpose:** The nerve center where final edits are reviewed.  
- **Atmosphere:** Dim lighting, a large projector screen, scattered hard drives, and tangled cables.  
- **Key Features:** Soundproofing foam panels on walls, a worn-out red velvet couch, and a rolling whiteboard with scribbled shot timings.  

### **B. Prop & Wardrobe Storage**  
- **Purpose:** Stores costumes, set pieces, and miscellaneous film artifacts.  
- **Atmosphere:** Cluttered but organized, with labeled plastic bins and garment racks.  
- **Key Features:** A vintage trunk full of period-accurate props, a mannequin wearing a key costume, and a broken stepladder.  

### **C. Miniature Set Construction Zone**  
- **Purpose:** Where small-scale dioramas for special effects are built.  
- **Atmosphere:** Sawdust in the air, scattered X-Acto knives, half-painted miniatures.  
- **Key Features:** A half-built miniature London street scene, a hot glue gun still plugged in, and a stack of reference artbooks.  

### **D. Equipment Storage & Repair Corner**  
- **Purpose:** Houses cameras, rigs, and broken gear awaiting fixes.  
- **Atmosphere:** A mix of high-tech and jury-rigged repairs (duct tape on a stabilizer).  
- **Key Features:** A heavy-duty Pelican case (locked), a tangled mess of HDMI cables, and a soldering iron left on a workbench.  

### **E. Break Nook / Informal Meeting Spot**  
- **Purpose:** Where the team takes quick coffee breaks and has impromptu discussions.  
- **Atmosphere:** Cozy but messy—dirty mugs, an old espresso machine, sticky notes everywhere.  
- **Key Features:** A bulletin board covered in festival acceptance letters and a chipped mug labeled "DIRECTOR’S CUP."  

---

## **3. Detailed Area-by-Area Inventory**  

### **A. Main Editing & Screening Lounge**  

#### **a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- A **large oak editing desk** (scratched surface, three monitors, a Wacom tablet)  
- A **projector screen** (slightly wrinkled, with faint coffee stains on the lower edge)  
- A **soundproofed recording booth** (glass walls, a Neumann U87 mic inside, a "RECORDING – DO NOT ENTER" sign)  

#### **b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **Final Cut Pro workstation** (one monitor displays an unresolved rendering error)  
- **External hard drive array** (labeled "ETHER MASTER – DO NOT TOUCH")  
- **A director’s notebook** (open to a page with circled notes: "Fix transition at 12:43!")  

#### **c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **Wireless keyboard** (missing the "E" key)  
- **Studio headphones** (left dangling on the chair)  
- **A mini-fridge** (humming loudly, contains energy drinks and leftover pizza)  

#### **d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **Film festival posters** (one from Seoul is slightly torn)  
- **A dried-out potted plant** (sits atop a stack of Blu-ray cases)  
- **A framed, unsigned check** ("For Film Rights – $500")  

---

### **B. Prop & Wardrobe Storage**  

#### **a. Anchor Furniture & Installations:**  
- **Industrial metal shelving units** (overstuffed with labeled plastic bins: "Victorian Era," "Modern Office")  
- **A freestanding clothing rack** (one wheel is broken, causing a tilt)  

#### **b. Key Interactive & Task-Relevant Objects:**  
- **A locked antique jewelry box** (contains the film’s pivotal "memory locket" prop)  
- **A steamer** (needs refilling, cord wrapped haphazardly)  
- **A mannequin** (wearing the protagonist’s signature green dress, missing one sleeve button)  

#### **c. Functional Ambient Objects:**  
- **A label maker** (out of tape)  
- **A stack of garment bags** (one has "RUKHSAAR’S WARDROBE" in Sharpie)  

#### **d. Background & Decorative Objects:**  
- **A dusty top hat** (perched on a shelf, unrelated to any film)  
- **A pile of rejected fabric swatches** (under a broken chair)  

---

## **4. Scene Affordances and Embedded Potential**  

### **Collaborative Transportation Affordances:**  
- **The Pelican case (Equipment Storage)** – Weight: **28kg**, dimensions: **120x60x50cm** – Requires two people to lift safely.  
- **The oak editing desk (Main Lounge)** – **Too bulky to move alone**, one wheel is stuck.  

### **Reasoning and Tool-Use Affordances:**  
- **Attribute-Based Reasoning:** Among five **hard drives** (all black, similar size), only one is labeled **"ETHER MASTER"** with a **red sticker** and **scratches on the corner**. A **decoy hard drive** nearby has the same label but lacks the scratches.  
- **Compound (Tool-Use) Reasoning:**  
  - **Problem:** The antique jewelry box (Prop Storage) is locked.  
  - **Solution:** The key is inside the **"DIRECTOR’S CUP"** in the Break Nook, buried under coffee grounds.  

---

This **hyper-detailed** environment is **ripe for multi-agent collaboration**, with **embedded puzzles**, **physical constraints**, and **layered reasoning challenges**. The **density of interactive and ambient objects** ensures realism while enabling **complex, dynamic tasks**.
